questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was brought to the ER by his friends after they found him lying unconscious next to an empty antifreeze bottle. Investigations were significant for the following findings. This condition predominantly affects which part of the kidney?

BUN - 60mg/dl

S. creatinine - 3.2mg/dl

S. potassium - 7mmol/L

ABG - high anion gap metabolic acidosis

Urine analysis - calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs).

Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens.

Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by:

  • Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin
  • Exogenous agents:  Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with urinary frequency, urgency, and burning during urination of two days duration. Presence of which of the following additional findings would make you suspect pyelonephritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules. 

The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate.  It is found in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific finding.

Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.

Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth. It is seen in renal TB.

questions.text: What is the most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
The most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis is Escherichia coli. 

The organisms that cause acute pyelonephritis include:

  • E. coli
  • Proteus
  • Klebsiella
  • Enterobacter species
  • Mycobacteria - caseating granulomatous inflammation
  • Fungi - non-caseating granulomatous inflammation
  • Viruses (CMV and adenovirus) - immunocompromised people

questions.text: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis.

Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are:

  • Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization)
  • Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla
  • Periglomerular fibrosis
  • Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring has occurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux

questions.text: A pathologist noted the following microscopic finding while examining a slide of a kidney. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

Option A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis.

Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates.

Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.

questions.text: All of the following patients are at risk of developing renal papillary necrosis except:

choices.text: A 14-year-old girl being treated for thalassemia major
A 60-year-old man with longstanding diabetes mellitus
A 46-year-old man with a history of analgesic abuse
A 24-year-old woman identified to have sickle cell trait

questions.solution:
Necrotizing papillitis or acute papillary necrosis is not associated with thalassemia.

Major causes of acute papillary necrosis include

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Sickle cell disease or trait
  • Analgesic abuse nephropathy
  • Obstruction by calculi
  • Focally in renal tuberculosis

Related Pearl: Causes of Papillary Necrosis in the Kidney

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with recurrent episodes of flank pain and fever with chills.  CECT abdomen showed dilated and enlarged left renal pelvis with the multiloculated calyces and resection of the kidney was done. The gross specimen showed large yellowish-orange nodules. Histological examination revealed foamy macrophages.  Which of the following is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histological findings are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is associated with Proteus infection and obstructive uropathy. 

Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritis characterized by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells, lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells.

The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused with renal cell carcinoma. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyces showing a multiloculated appearance referred to as the bear paw sign.

questions.text:
Which of the following do not result in granular contracted kidneys?
  1. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  2. Benign nephrosclerosis
  3. Chronic pyelonephritis
  4. Amyloidosis
  5. Chronic glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and amyloidosis cause enlarged kidneys.

Causes of contracted kidneys:

  • Symmetric
    • Chronic glomerulonephritis 
    • Benign nephrosclerosis
  • Asymmetric
    • Chronic pyelonephritis

Causes of enlarged kidneys:

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
  • Amyloidosis
  • Polycystic kidney disease
  • Hydronephrosis (bilateral obstruction)

The following image shows the gross appearance in benign nephrosclerosis illustrating the fine, leathery granularity of the surface.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not associated with malignant hypertension?
questions.solution:
Image 4 shows a leather-grain appearance, which is seen in benign nephrosclerosis.

Features of malignant hypertension:

  • Flea bitten kidney - small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface, leading to a mottled appearance
  • Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles - cytologic detail is lost and the vessel wall takes on a smudgy eosinophilic appearance due to fibrin deposition
  • Onion-skinning (hyperplastic arterioles) - intimal thickening with the fine concentric layering of collagen & smooth muscles

The differential diagnosis for flea-bitten kidney includes:

  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE)
  • Malignant hypertension

questions.text: Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome can be caused by all except:
questions.solution:
Deficiency of ADAMTS13 leads to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Two common pathogenetic triggers of thrombotic microangiopathies are:

  • Endothelial injury - HUS
  • Excessive platelet activation and aggregation - TTP
Typical HUS Atypical HUS

5-10 days after diarrheal illness

E.coli O157:H7 or Shigella dysenteriae type I

Mutation in genes encoding complement regulatory protein
  • Shiga-like toxins produced cause endothelial damage.
  • This leads to platelet activation and thrombi.

Uncontrolled activation of the complement system due to:

  • Antiphospholipid antibodies
  • Pregnancy complications
  • OCPs
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought with blood in the urine. His mother says he had bloody diarrhea, fever, and vomiting 10 days ago. His BP is 130/90 mm Hg, and he is jaundiced. Investigations reveal a platelet count of 50,000 cells/cu mm,  BUN of 35mg/dl, and creatinine of 3.5mg/dl. Which of the following cells would you expect to see in the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is characterized by the presence of schistocytes in peripheral smear. It indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. 

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Peripheral blood smear

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency 

Heinz bodies (revealed by special staining),‘Bite’ cells

questions.text: Cholemic nephrosis is associated with which of the following casts?
questions.solution:
Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile.

In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may be impaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevated bilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephron segments.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the polycystin gene?

choices.text: Polycystin-1 is most commonly involved in ADPKD
Polycystin-2 is a calcium ion channel
Mutation in polycystin-2 causes more severe form of ADPKD
Polycystin-1 is involved in cell interactions

questions.solution:
The polycystin-2 mutation is less commonly involved and less severe.

Polycystin-1 is encoded by the PKD1 gene located on chromosome 16p13.3. It is expressed in tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron. It contains domains that are usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. Mutations in PKD1 account for about 85% of cases of ADPKD (autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) and it causes a more severe form of the disease.

Polycystin-2 is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules and in many extrarenal tissues. It functions as a Ca2+ cation channel. Overall, it causes a less severe form of ADPKD disease.

questions.text: What is the most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is the liver.

40% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts are derived from the biliary epithelium.

Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved.

questions.text: In patients with ADPKD,  the mutated genes are located on which chromosomes?
questions.solution:
The genes mutated in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are located on chromosomes 16 and 4.

This condition occurs due to mutations of the PKD1 gene (chromosome 16) and PKD2 gene (on chromosome 4). These genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins respectively.

questions.text: Mutations in fibrocystin are seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6p21-p23 which encodes fibrocystin.

The gene is highly expressed in adult and fetal kidneys and also in the liver and pancreas. Fibrocystin has been localized to the primary cilium of tubular cells.

The serious manifestations of ARPKD are usually present at birth, and may cause death by renal failure. The following gross findings are seen:

  • Enlarged kidneys with smooth external appearance
  • Spongelike appearance due to numerous small cysts in the cortex and medulla
  • Dilated elongated channels at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing the medulla and cortex

On microscopic examination, there is cylindrical or, less commonly, saccular dilation of all collecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells. In almost all cases, the liver has cysts associated with portal fibrosis and proliferation of the portal bile ducts, termed congenital hepatic fibrosis.

questions.text: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A routine urine examination of a 46-year-old woman shows thorn-apple crystals. Past history is significant for constipation and longstanding use of laxatives. What is the likely composition of these crystals?
questions.solution:
Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregular projections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: In patients with chronic kidney disease, what type of casts are seen?
questions.solution:
Broad casts are seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). They are also known as renal failure casts.

Broad casts are defined as those with a diameter 2-6 times that of normal casts. They indicate chronically damaged tubules or collecting ducts. They indicate a poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance
